docTitle.titlePart: Immobilization of enzymes by multilayer microcapsules

byline.docAuthor: Rainer Pommersheim, Jiirgen Schrezenmeir, Walter Vogt *

front.div:
SUMMARY A method is described to obtain a new type of microcapsules for immobilization of enzymes
or living cells. The wall of these capsules consists of several layers of poly(ethy1eneimine) and
poly(acry1ic acid). The idea is that diverging properties of the whole assembly can be better
controlled when the membrane is built up by several consecutive steps, each being optimized with
respect to a special property, for example, permeability or mechanical strength. The encapsulation
of acidic phosphatase and the cleavage of p-nitrophenyl phosphate was used as a model system.
The charged capsules were characterized by their enzymatic activity, as a function of membrane
composition (number and sequence of layers) and storing time. The permeability for the substrate
and the retaining ability for the enzyme were also measured.
